title: Patrick Wolf
text:
{{Short description|English singer-songwriter}} {{other people}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2020}} {{Use British English|date=March 2012}} {{Infobox musical artist | image = Patrick Wolf Montreal.jpg | caption = Patrick Wolf in 2007 | name = Patrick Wolf | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Patrick Denis Apps | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1983|6|30|df=y}} | birth_place = [[London]], England | origin = | instruments = Piano, [[electronic keyboard|keyboards]], [[ukulele]], [[viola]], violin, guitar, bass, [[mandolin]], [[kantele]], [[dulcimer]], [[accordion]] | genre = [[Baroque pop]], [[folktronica]], [[trip hop]] | occupation = Singer-songwriter | years_active = 2002–present | label = [[Low Altitude Records]]
[[Faith & Industry]]
[[Tomlab]]
[[Loog Records|Loog]]
[[Bloody Chamber Music]]
[[Mercury Records]] | website = {{Official URL}} | associated_acts = [[Tilda Swinton]], [[Eliza Carthy]], [[Buffy Sainte-Marie]] }} '''Patrick Wolf''' (born '''Patrick Denis Apps'''; 30 June 1983) is an English singer-songwriter from [[South London]]. Wolf uses a wide variety of instruments in his music, most commonly the [[ukulele]], piano, and [[viola]]. He is known for combining electronic sampling with classical instruments. Wolf's styles range from electronic pop to [[Baroque chamber music]]. ==Biography== Patrick Wolf was born in [[St Thomas' Hospital]],{{cite web|url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/lifestyle/article-23692625-my-london-patrick-wolf.do|title=My London: Patrick Wolf|last=Grier|first=Amy|date=15 May 2009|publisher=London Evening Standard|access-date=4 November 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100620052234/http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/lifestyle/article-23692625-my-london-patrick-wolf.do|archive-date=20 June 2010|url-status=dead}} [[South London]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nme.com/artists/patrick-wolf|title=Patrick Wolf|publisher=[[NME]]}}{{cite web|url=http://www.starpulse.com/Music/Wolf,_Patrick/index.html|title=Patrick Wolf Biography, Discography, Ringtones, Video|publisher=Star}} He attended [[King's College School]]Phillips, Matt, 2009 [http://lookingglassuk.blogspot.nl/2009/11/schools-for-unnaturally-gifted.html ''Schools for unnaturally gifted'', The Looking Glass] and [[Bedales School]].{{cite web |title=The interview: Patrick Wolf |last=Sawyer |first=Miranda |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2009/apr/19/patrick-wolf-interview |work=The Guardian |access-date=29 June 2011 |date=19 April 2009}} ===''Lycanthropy'' and ''Wind in the Wires''=== Wolf's ongoing writing and recordings brought him to the attention of [[Fat Cat Records]], who provided him with an Atari computer and a mixing console. During the recording of ''[[Lycanthropy (album)|Lycanthropy]]'', Wolf studied composition at [[Trinity College of Music]] for one year. ''Lycanthropy'' was released in the summer of 2003. He also made some guest appearances as a viola player with [[Chicks on Speed]], [[Arcade Fire]], [[Owen Pallett]], [[CocoRosie]], and [[The Hidden Cameras]]. The Germany-based [[Tomlab]] later released the album in America and Europe. His second album of 2005, ''[[Wind In The Wires]]'', which was inspired by Patrick's Cornish and Irish roots, was released on the same label and likewise met with critical acclaim. The single ''Tristan'', based on the Cornish legend, Tristram of Lyonesse, received significant attention from critics and remains a fan favourite. ===''The Magic Position''=== Following the success of ''Wind in the Wires'', Wolf signed a record deal with [[Loog Records|Loog]] in 2005 and began recording his third album, ''[[The Magic Position]]'', which featured collaborations with [[Marianne Faithfull]] and [[Edward Larrikin]] of [[Larrikin Love]].{{cite web| url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=K-tNpyogrSw |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211213/K-tNpyogrSw |archive-date=2021-12-13 |url-status=live| title=Patrick Wolf vodcast| website=[[YouTube]]| access-date=5 February 2007}}{{cbignore}} Its official release on 26 February met with critical acclaim, and gained a degree of commercial success due to the relative accessibility compared to his previous works.{{Citation needed|date=February 2009}} ''The Magic Position'' was released in the United States on Low Altitude Records on 1 May 2007.[http://exclaim.ca/articles/multiarticlesub.aspx?csid1=110&csid2=4&fid1=25097 'The Amorphous Patrick Wolf'] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071120234547/http://www.exclaim.ca/articles/multiarticlesub.aspx?csid1=110&csid2=4&fid1=25097 |date=20 November 2007 }} Exclaim.ca A concept album on the theme of love, the majority of the album was written after the end of a long term intimate relationship. In January 2007, the first of six [[Video podcast|vodcast]]s was made available on [[iTunes]]. The series included live performances of old and new material and interviews. Wolf promoted the album with a concert tour in North America, Europe, Japan, and Australia, culminating in two sold out nights at London's [[Shepherd's Bush Empire]]. Both of these shows, which were shot and directed by photographer Brantley Gutierrez, are in development to be shown on a Virgin channel and then released on DVD. ===''The Bachelor'' and ''Lupercalia''=== Wolf began work on his next album, initially titled ''Battle'', immediately after ''The Magic Position'' tour ended. The album was originally conceived as a political album. The focus then shifted to the depression experienced by Wolf during the tour. However, before entering the studio, he fell in love, changing the direction of the album again, and eventually providing enough material for two releases. Wolf parted ways with Universal Records, and on 10 December 2008 announced to ''NME'' his plan to sell £10 shares of the album on bandstocks.com: "Basically, you can invest in the finishing of the album and the production of it, and you get a share in the album. So you almost become part of the record company, like a co-owner of the album."{{cite web|url=http://www.idiomag.com/peek/65459/patrick_wolf|title=Patrick Wolf Talks New Album|access-date=19 February 2009|date=18 February 2009|publisher=[[idiomag]]}} On 12 February 2009, Wolf announced that the two discs would be titled ''The Bachelor'' and ''The Conqueror'' (although the latter album title has subsequently been changed). ''[[The Bachelor (album)|The Bachelor's]]'' first single, "[[Vulture (song)|Vulture]]", was released on 2 April 2009, on vinyl and digital download. The B-sides include new song, "The Tinderbox", and remixes of the title track. ''The Bachelor'' was released on 1 June 2009, while the second single from the album, "[[Hard Times (Patrick Wolf song)|Hard Times]]", was released on 6 July 2009. The third and final single, "[[Damaris (Patrick Wolf song)|Damaris]]", was released on 14 December 2009.{{cite web|title=New details about Patrick Wolf's Battle emerge|url=http://www.kwamecorp.com/bandstocksnews/2009/02/changes-made-to-patrick-wolfs.html|publisher=Kwamecorp.com|access-date=29 June 2014}} In April 2010 it was announced that Wolf had signed a record deal with Hideout, a subsidiary of [[Mercury Records]], which released his fifth album, ‘’[[Lupercalia (album)|Lupercalia]]‘’. The final title was announced via Twitter on 23 December 2010.{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/_PATRICK_WOLF/status/17861924951687168 |title=Twitter |publisher=Twitter |access-date=29 June 2014}} On 4 November 2010, Wolf announced that the first single from ''Lupercalia'' was to be "[[Time of My Life (Patrick Wolf song)|Time of My Life]]" and the song was uploaded onto YouTube. Of the song, Wolf said: "'Time of My Life' is a song that I began writing at the end of a relationship in 2006 and then finished three years later during a temporary break-up in my current relationship. The new album has a direct narrative about love and optimism surviving through adversity and recession. I wanted to celebrate the love and hope I have found in the last few years." The song was released on 6 December 2010. He also announced that ''Lupercalia'' would be released in May 2011. On 10 January 2011, Wolf announced on his official Twitter account that the second single from the album, "The City", would be released on 14 March 2011.{{update after|2011|03|14}}{{cite web|url=http://zaphod.uk.vvhp.net/consumer/viewemailcontent.pl?con=9914521&cmp=5599&act=156987&sec=acd4a64163f8&webversionpage=1|title=Patrick Wolf: Patrick Wolf to tour Russia|publisher=[[Universal Music]]|access-date=29 June 2014}}{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/_PATRICK_WOLF/status/24478360063184897|title=Patrick Wolf |publisher=Twitter|access-date=29 June 2014}} On 6 April 2011, Wolf released ''Lupercalia'' 20 June 2011 worldwide (excluding USA, where it was released 28 June 2011).{{cite web|url=http://www.patrickwolf.com/ |title=Gigography, Gallery, Lyrics, Discography, Wolf TV |publisher=Patrick Wolf |access-date=30 April 2012}} In the same month, Wolf was featured on the cover of national UK publication ''[[Notion (magazine)|Notion)]]'', which included an interview conducted by writer [[Alex Lee Thomson]], clothes by [[James Long (fashion designer)|James Long]], and photos by James Moriarty. In October 2011, Wolf accepted an "Outstanding Contribution To the Arts" award from [[Trinity LGBT]].{{cite web|last=Twomey|first=Peter|title=Patrick Wolf collects Qsoc's 'Outstanding Contribution to the Arts' award|url=http://universitytimes.ie/?p=5812|publisher=[[The University Times]]|access-date=20 September 2013}} === ''Sundark and Riverlight'' and ''The Ghost Region''=== On 18 May 2012 Wolf announced that he was working on his next album, to be released later in the year: "I'm going back to the studio and recording my jubilee record... The album will be totally, totally, totally stripped down. It's time for me to be retrospective about the last ten years before I move onto the next ten. I'm 28 and I think it's quite fun to sing the songs you wrote as a teenager."{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/triplej/musicnews/s3505858.htm |title=Exclusive: Patrick Wolf to release jubilee record | music news | triple j |publisher=Abc.net.au |date=1 May 2012|access-date=29 June 2014}} It was announced on 9 August that his next release would be a double album entitled ''[[Sundark and Riverlight]]'', celebrating Wolf's 10 years as a recording artist. The album will feature acoustic re-recordings of songs from throughout his career, as well as previously unheard tracks. It will be released on 25 September.{{cite web|url=http://www.nme.com/news/patrick-wolf/65426 |title=Patrick Wolf to release double album 'Sundark & Riverlight' | News |publisher=Nme.Com |date=9 August 2012 |access-date=29 June 2014}} The title song, a remake of ''Overture'' originally from the album ''The Magic Position'', was released on YouTube and then on iTunes on 7 September. ''[[Sundark and Riverlight]]'' is now available to stream in full online.{{cite news | title = Listen: Patrick Wolf – 'Sundark & Riverlight | date = 10 October 2012 | url = http://www.clixie.co.uk/listen-patrick-wolf-sundark-riverlight/ | work = Clixie | access-date = 14 October 2012}} In March 2012 he announced on BBC Radio 6's Tom Robinson Show that he would be taking the first sabbatical of his career before pursuing the next chapter of his musical journey.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p016gz7z |title=BBC Radio 6 Music – The Tom Robinson Show, Patrick Wolf joins Tom Robinson |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |access-date=29 June 2014}} The Sundark and Riverlight tour ended on 6 April at London's Queen Elizabeth Hall. In 2013, Wolf went on to finish the last dates of [[Patti Smith]]'s [[Banga (album)|Banga]] tour on Celtic harp and viola.{{cite web|title=Wylie Music presents: A Night Of Winter with PATRICK WOLF|url=http://store.unionchapel.org.uk/events/21-dec-13-a-night-of-winter-with-patrick-wolf-union-chapel/|publisher=[[Union Chapel, Islington|Union Chapel]]|access-date=20 September 2013}} In July 2015, details were announced of a poetry book written by Patrick entitled ''The Ghost Region''.{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/patrickwolf/photos/a.10150722704929320.417519.6229419319/10153520655764320/?type=3&theater|title=Patrick Wolf on Twitter|website=Facebook.com|date=17 August 2017|access-date=16 December 2017}} ===Hiatus=== Following the release of ''Sundark and Riverlight'', Wolf experienced "a general burn-out, ill-timed to coincide with a 'cluster-fuck of financial and legal problems regarding management'"; until 2015, he spent time writing, alone, in a makeshift studio in a South London stable block. In August that year, having announced pre-orders for his poetry collection, ''The Ghost Region'', he was hit by a car on holiday in [[Venice]], shortly after which his mother fell ill. Of this period Wolf stated: "It completely whacked me out for six... I'm very happy to be here right now. I'll leave it at that."{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/apr/12/patrick-wolf-on-the-car-accident-and-his-comeback-it-completely-whacked-me-out-for-six|title=Patrick Wolf on the car accident and his comeback: 'It completely whacked me out for six'|first=Jared|last=Richards|date=12 April 2018|access-date=3 January 2021|website=Theguardian.com}} ===Edmund Burke Medal from Trinity College Historical Society=== In October 2017, it was announced that he was to receive The Edmund Burke Medal from [[Trinity College, Dublin|Trinity College Historical Society, Dublin]] the following December for Outstanding Contribution to Discourse through the Arts, becoming the first LGBT artist to do so, and to celebrate he would be doing one-off gigs in Dublin and London, which would be his only shows for the year. He also confirmed that he was in the final stages of recording his album and getting ready to release his poetry book ''The Ghost Region'', which had originally been made available for pre-order two years earlier.{{cite web|url=https://www.readdork.com/features/highlights-patrick-wolf-on-his-standout-tracks/|title=Highlights: Patrick Wolf on his standout tracks|website=Readdork.com|date=11 December 2017|access-date=12 December 2017}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.readdork.com/news/patrick-wolf-has-won-a-medal-and-is-playing-some-shows-to-celebrate/|title=Patrick Wolf has won a medal and is playing some shows to celebrate|website=Readdork.com|language=en|access-date=27 July 2018}} ===Musical activities from 2018 onward=== Wolf had resumed touring by July 2018, including in [[Australia]], where he planned to mix an album while staying in the New South Wales Blue Mountains. He had also completed the poetry book he had been working on in 2015. The Telegraph reviewed Wolf's "comeback", the first of three shows at the St Pancras Old Church in London in January 2020, noting, despite occasional "bum notes" and "forgotten lyrics", that the performance offered "exquisite highs", and Wolf's songs were noted to be "wildly dramatic and original... with vivid lyrics and exuberant melodic flair".{{Cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/music/what-to-listen-to/patrick-wolf-review-st-pancras-old-church-comeback-full-bum/|title=Patrick Wolf review, St Pancras Old Church: a comeback full of bum notes, forgotten lyrics and exquisite highs|first=Neil|last=McCormick|date=16 January 2020|access-date=3 January 2021|website=Telegraph.co.uk}} ==Personal life== Wolf reflects that as a teenager, he was [[bullying|bullied]] at school in [[Wimbledon, London|Wimbledon]] for his perceived eccentricity and effeminacy. He stated: "Wimbledon is my trauma area".{{cite web|author=Neil Scott |url=http://www.tmcq.co.uk/interviews/patrick-wolf/ |title=Patrick Wolf |work=The Mind’s Construction Quarterly |access-date=29 June 2014}} At the time, he was unsure whether he was [[homosexuality|gay]] or [[bisexuality|bisexual]]. Mentors at school treated him with disdain when he came to them for support on the issue. The bullying problem was only rectified after his mother changed schools. Wolf comments, "With gay or bi people, I think education still wonders if it's a nature-versus-nurture thing. If you were black, they'd know they couldn't change you, and racist bullying would never be condoned, but if someone is quite feminine or knows they might be gay at 13, they think they can change you with a bit of [[rugby union|rugby]]". On 27 February 2007, in an interview with ''[[The London Paper]]'', Wolf raised questions about his sexuality: "In the same way I don’t know if my sixth album is going to be a death-metal record or children's pop, I don’t know whether I’m destined to live my life with a horse, a woman or a man. It makes life easier".{{cite web |url=http://www.thelondonpaper.com/cs/Satellite/london/music/article/1157145572163?packedargs=suffix%3DArticleController&c |title=The lone Wolf of indie |access-date=8 April 2007 |last=Mackenzie |first=Malcolm |date=27 February 2007 |work=thelondonpaper |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927014124/http://www.thelondonpaper.com/cs/Satellite/london/music/article/1157145572163?packedargs=suffix=ArticleController&c |archive-date=27 September 2007 }} In a 5 July 2007 interview with [[Sydney]]'s ''[[Star Observer]]'', he confirmed his sexuality: "My sexuality is kind of liberal. I fall in love with men and women. I guess you would call me bisexual. I like to have sex and fall in love—I don't like giving terminology for my sexuality".{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2008/sep/02/patrick.wolf.double.album |title=Patrick Wolf to return with double album |date=2 October 2008 |last=Michaels |first=Sean |work=[[The Guardian]]}}{{cite news |last=Burns |first=Sunny |title=Putting some growl into pop |work=[[Star Observer]] |date=17 August 2007 |url=http://www.ssonet.com.au/display.asp?ArticleID=6728 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080212070446/http://www.ssonet.com.au/display.asp?ArticleID=6728 |archive-date=12 February 2008 |access-date=31 December 2009}}{{cite web |url=https://twitter.com/_PATRICK_WOLF/status/21056054938836993 |title=this is the happiest new years day and day of my life. william charles pollock has asked for my hand in marriage. finally. finally. my man x |publisher=[[Twitter]] |access-date=29 June 2014}} Later, in 2009, Wolf told ''[[The Guardian]]'' that though in the past he has had relationships with women, he currently identifies himself as gay. As an artist, Wolf reflects that he doesn't like to worry about whether he makes a record "too gay or too straight or too this or too that". ==Modelling== Wolf, along with [[The Paddingtons]], [[Edward Larrikin]], and [[The View (band)|The View]], was featured in a series of photographs by [[Mario Testino]] as a part of a campaign for [[Burberry]] in August 2007.{{cite news | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1554574/Check-out-Burberrys-new-talent.html | title = Check out Burberry's new talent | last = Coulson | first = Clare | date = 15 June 2007 | work = The Telegraph | access-date = 10 June 2009}} In 2011, a portrait of Wolf was painted by British artist [[Joe Simpson (artist)|Joe Simpson]], the painting was exhibited around the UK including a solo exhibition at [[The Royal Albert Hall]]. ==Discography== {{Main|Patrick Wolf discography}} * ''[[Lycanthropy (album)|Lycanthropy]]'' (2003) * ''[[Wind in the Wires]]'' (2005) * ''[[The Magic Position]]'' (2007) * ''[[The Bachelor (album)|The Bachelor]]'' (2009) * ''[[Lupercalia (album)|Lupercalia]]'' (2011) * ''[[Sundark and Riverlight]]'' (2012) ==Bloody Chamber Music== {{Infobox record label |name = Bloody Chamber Music |image = |location = London |founded = 2008 |founder = Patrick Wolf |genre = Pop, [[Alternative rock|Alternative]] |country = UK }} Bloody Chamber Music is an independent record label founded by Patrick Wolf.{{cite web|url=http://www.nme.com/news/patrick-wolf/32139|title=Patrick Wolf launches his own record label |publisher=[[NME]]|date=29 October 2007|access-date=14 April 2012}} Label was named after Angela Carter's book, ''The Bloody Chamber'', that thrilled Wolf in his early years.{{cite web|url=http://disconaivete.com/post/922048096/interview-with-patrick-wolf|title=Interview with Patrick Wolf|publisher=Disco Naivete}} Wolf originally started the label as somewhere to store his digital back-catalogue of music. However, he has since explained that due to music piracy, as well as the current economic climate, some artists have been finding it difficult to stay in music. Bloody Chamber Music is a label which will allow such artists to follow their vocation, and be supported by their fans.{{cite video|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mWMbN-xv4G8 |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211213/mWMbN-xv4G8 |archive-date=2021-12-13 |url-status=live|title=Patrick Wolf – Journal – Chapter Two |publisher=Patrick Wolf TV|date=11 December 2008|access-date=14 April 2012}}{{cbignore}} ===Bandstocks=== Bandstocks was an early music crowdfunding website. Patrick Wolf collaborated with his fans through Bandstocks for his album release, [[The Bachelor (album)|The Bachelor]]. ===Artists=== *Patrick Wolf *Craig Template{{cite web|url=http://themusicalchairs.blogspot.com/2007/10/bloody-chamber-music.html|title=Bloody Chamber Music |last=Raymond|first=Max|date=30 October 2007|publisher=Musical Chairs|access-date=14 April 2012}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb name|id=2540956}} * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zUbxx1kQTBs/ Interview in Virgin Red Room] * [http://www.exberliner.com/articles/interview-patrick-wolf/ Interview in Exberliner Magazine] {{Patrick Wolf}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Wolf, Patrick}} [[Category:1983 births]] [[Category:21st-century English singers]] [[Category:21st-century pianists]] [[Category:Alumni of Trinity College of Music]] [[Category:English buskers]] [[Category:English electronic musicians]] [[Category:English male singers]] [[Category:English people of Cornish descent]] [[Category:English people of Irish descent]] [[Category:English pianists]] [[Category:English record producers]] [[Category:English songwriters]] [[Category:English gay musicians]] [[Category:Gay models]] [[Category:LGBT singers from the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People educated at King's College School, London]] [[Category:Singers from London]] [[Category:British record labels]] [[Category:Record labels established in 2008]] [[Category:Pop record labels]] [[Category:Downtempo musicians]] [[Category:British male pianists]] [[Category:21st-century British male singers]] [[Category:20th-century LGBT people]] [[Category:21st-century LGBT people]] [[Category:Pop violists]] [[Category:British male songwriters]]
